(CASTELLANO) No reinventa nada, pero s√≠ consigue lo que muchas pel√≠culas del g√©nero ni se molestan en intentar: entretener de principio a fin. Transformers: El despertar de las bestias se mueve al ritmo de la acci√≥n casi sin pausa, con una energ√≠a que no decae y que consigue que las dos horas se pasen volando. Es puro blockbuster, sin complejos. A diferencia de entregas anteriores, aqu√≠ se nota cierta intenci√≥n de dar algo m√°s de peso emocional. No es que sea una pel√≠cula dram√°tica, ni mucho menos, pero s√≠ tiene algunos momentos tristes que sorprenden por lo bien colocados que est√°n en medio del caos. Y eso, en una saga acostumbrada al ruido por el ruido, se agradece. Visualmente est√° al nivel que se espera de una superproducci√≥n de este calibre: efectos espectaculares, batallas enormes y una puesta en escena que saca todo el partido a los Transformers. Adem√°s, la ambientaci√≥n noventera y la banda sonora con toques de hip hop a√±aden personalidad y un punto nost√°lgico que funciona bastante bien. ¬øEs predecible? Por supuesto. ¬øEst√° llena de clich√©s? Tambi√©n. Pero lo cierto es que funciona. Y parte de eso se debe a un reparto que cumple con creces, con Anthony Ramos y Dominique Fishback aportando humanidad a una historia dominada por m√°quinas. (ENGLISH) It doesn‚Äôt reinvent the wheel, but it does manage something many blockbusters don‚Äôt even try: to entertain from start to finish. Transformers: Rise of the Beasts moves at full speed, with non-stop action and energy that never dips. It‚Äôs unapologetic popcorn cinema at its best. Unlike some previous entries, this one actually tries to inject a bit more emotional weight. It‚Äôs not a tearjerker by any means, but there are a few surprisingly touching moments that are well-placed amidst all the chaos. And for a franchise that usually goes all in on noise, that‚Äôs a welcome change. Visually, it delivers exactly what you'd expect from a big-budget production: spectacular effects, massive battles, and a scale that fully embraces the Transformers‚Äô potential. The ‚Äò90s vibe and the hip-hop-infused soundtrack give it extra flair and just the right dose of nostalgia. Is it predictable? Absolutely. Full of clich√©s? For sure. But it works. And a big part of that is thanks to a cast that brings heart to the metal, especially Anthony Ramos and Dominique Fishback, who ground the story with some much-needed humanity. It might not be the best of the saga, but it‚Äôs one of the most balanced. It knows what it wants to be and doesn‚Äôt try to be anything else. Action, spectacle, and just the right touch of emotion. Sometimes, that‚Äôs all you need.

'Transformers: Rise of the Beasts' continues this franchise's fine tradition of (mostly) underwhelming me, though to be honest it does match predecessor 'Bumblebee' in at least making its plot more than just robots smashing into each other. I wouldn't file it under 'bad', to be fair. The brotherly bond between the characters of Anthony Ramos and Dean Scott Vazquez is this movie's best element, in my opinion. I found that to be touching, even if the film doesn't utilise it as much as it perhaps could have. Aside from those, Dominique Fishback is the best of the humans. As for the voices, Pete Davidson is good in this as Mirage - I think he might be my 'favourite' robot from this whole series. Davidson is lively in the role, amusing too. Peter Dinklage is a mini positive as well, even though I would've preferred if they didn't alter his usual voice as much. Looks like I am going to have to now watch the 'G.I. Joe' franchise at some point, at least that only has three flicks. Well, for now. I best be quick before they pump them out as quickly as 'Transformers' did.

**Transformers: Rise of the Beasts** - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ As a big *Transformers* fan, I was super excited for *Rise of the Beasts*. Hearing Peter Cullen as Optimus Prime again is always awesome, and Bumblebee is still my favorite! The CGI looked really good, and the Transformers and Maximals were cool to watch. The voice cast did a great job, and you can watch this as a prequel, sequel, or even on its own. The action scenes were fun and there were some funny moments too. But the story felt really thin and could have used more backstory. It got a bit boring and predictable at times, and I wish we saw more of the Maximals. That said, there were some great sequences, and the ending got me excited for what‚Äôs next. Overall, it‚Äôs not the best *Transformers* movie, but it‚Äôs definitely not the worst. If you‚Äôre a fan, it‚Äôs worth a watch!

I have watched all 7 Transformers films, some many times. The first is still a masterpiece, with Shia LaBeouf and ensemble cast around him setting the bar so high that no one has matched it since. In 2007 this was all very groundbreaking. But even then a tendency to have over long action sequences when literally nothing interesting happens. Bumble Bee with Hailee Steinfield was another high water mark. the tone and her star role make this a very memorable and re-weatchable film. I note that the producers felt Bumble bee lacked the big set action that audiences need, but for me, real human interactions and this more down to earth scale was really good and they should try and capture that again. So for 'Rise of the Beasts', allegedly an opportunity to combine the human scale of BB with human characters we care about. But unforunately the actors may well be good in this, but the script does not allow them to be truly witty and deep characters. It feels like mindless action rules again. The trailer looked promising, but I wont watch any more Transformers, unless strong witty human characters and more human real scale stories take centre stage again. This one is sadly such a missed opportunity.

Transformers: Rise of the Beasts is a solid entry in the franchise, delivering high-octane action and visually striking sequences. Yet, it falters in replicating Michael Bay‚Äôs iconic style; its attempt at chaotic energy and relentless explosions feels like a disjointed imitation, lacking the immersive coherence Bay is known for. Set in 1994, the film introduces the Maximals, with Ron Perlman‚Äôs Optimus Primal leading a team that joins forces with the Autobots, headed by Peter Cullen‚Äôs Optimus Prime, to battle the planet-devouring Unicron. Peter Dinklage‚Äôs portrayal of Scourge adds a darkly humorous edge to the villain role, but it is Pete Davidson‚Äôs Mirage who stands out with his irreverent and hilarious voice work, injecting a vibrant comedic energy into the film. Michelle Yeoh‚Äôs Airazor and Cristo Fern√°ndez‚Äôs Wheeljack further enrich the character roster with their distinctive contributions. Human leads Anthony Ramos and Dominique Fishback deliver compelling performances as Noah Diaz and Elena Wallace, infusing the film with emotional depth and reinforcing themes of family and perseverance. Despite its impressive visuals and engaging performances, Rise of the Beasts struggles to leave a lasting impact, falling short of innovation while providing a satisfying, if conventional, adventure.

After watching all the Transformer films that came before Rise of the Beasts, I would say this one is probably the best. However, the film ultimately still suffers from horrible character development with the humans being forced into the situation without any personal connection to the story and with half of the autobots not being introduced or explained whatsoever. Another issue is the plot. It's just another "save the artifact and save the world" gig, with the ultimate bad guy, Unicron, having no motive other then to eat planets. Unicron doesnt even look cool. The pacing and action are better in this film than in the previous Transformers movies, this in the 21st century, that will only get you so many stars. I agree with other critics as well that the overall philosophy and code of ethics of the autobots is very unclear.

It gets a pass for not being as visually impressive. There really are parts that make you cringe enough to want to fast forward. It hits certain "modern tropes" really on the nose. Optimus Prime doesn't feel like Optimus.

While it may not have the jaw dropping visual scope of the Michael Bay series, they up the ante from Bumblebee while retaining coherent story telling with good characters. Again they do a better job at fleshing out the human characters & their motivation being involved in the story. Optimus prime has a good character arc & movie does a solid intro to the primals. They definitely borrowed designs for antagonists from Lord of the Rings. The soundtrack with heavy hip-hop from 90's was pretty dope & matched the vibe of the story. First 2 acts of movie swiftly with interesting set pieces, but slows down in the 3rd with a CGI heavy final act we are accustomed to in the past decade from blockbuster movies. However, I am genuinely interested in how they will continue to expand this storyline in the Hasbro universe they're building. Solid movie on a big screen.

Transformers: Rise of the Beasts is a thrilling and fresh addition to the franchise that revitalizes the series with new energy and bold, exciting characters. The introduction of the Maximals adds an exhilarating new layer to the Transformers universe, offering fans a dynamic blend of nostalgia and innovation. The action sequences are electrifying, and the visual effects are nothing short of spectacular, making every transformation and battle scene a feast for the eyes. The film balances its epic scale with a grounded story, and the chemistry between the cast brings warmth and heart to the adventure. Rise of the Beasts is a triumphant return to form, delivering everything fans love about the series while pushing it forward in exciting new directions. It's definitely a must-watch and this is truly the best Transformers movie yet!

Transformers: Rise of the Beasts - A Robot Rumble That Totally Misses the Mark While Transformers: Rise of the Beasts boasts impressive visuals and some exciting action sequences, it ultimately sputters under the weight of a generic plot, forgettable characters, and an over-reliance on nostalgia. Here's what explodes: ‚Ä¢ Spectacular CGI: The film's special effects are undeniably impressive, bringing the transforming robots to life in dazzling detail. ‚Ä¢ Action-Packed Fights: The battles between the Autobots, Decepticons, and newcomers, the Maximals, are undeniably thrilling to watch on the big screen. However, these positives get buried under a heap of negatives: ‚Ä¢ Rehashed Plot: The story offers little that's new or inventive, relying on familiar beats and predictable plot twists. ‚Ä¢ Shallow Characters: Both the human characters and the Transformers themselves lack depth or development, making it hard to connect with them. ‚Ä¢ Nostalgia Overload: The film leans heavily on references to past Transformers films, which might feel pandering to some viewers. ‚Ä¢ HORRIBLE ACTING, DIRECTION and WRITING !!! ‚Ä¢ Forgettable Experience: Despite the big visuals and action, the film fails to leave a lasting impression. Transformers: Rise of the Beasts might appeal to die-hard Transformers fans looking for a visual spectacle. But for casual viewers, it's a noisy and generic experience that offers little substance beyond the special effects. This disappointing sequel earns a mediocre 2.0 out of 5 stars. NOT worth investing any time watching, let‚Äôs hope the next installment is better!!! - Matthew

Rise of the Beasts tries to bridge the gap between Bumblebee and the Transformers movies prior, but it ends up feeling more like the prior movies compared to continuing where Bumblebee left the franchise off. Even though this was not a direct sequel to Bumblebee, I was hoping that they would take that's movies strengths and apply them to this movie, but sadly it feels like the only thing that got carried over was the Generation 1 paintjob and that is about it. But it is not from a lack of trying. You can see that they wanted to re-create what Charlie had with Bumblebee with Mirage and Noah, but the spark isn't there this time around. Mirage is more unlikable than Bumblebee due to his comedic attempts landing flat and all around irritating nature. Noah is forgettable from both a writing and performance standpoint compared to Charlie. Noah's lone wolf to team player narrative is also not as interesting to watch. Elana is also pretty forgettable and is only really there for the plot. The Maximals and the Terrocons are interesting enough additions to the mythology and do a serviceable job. The action is what you expect from one of these movies, however the third act seems way too over the top and has a few too many dumb ideas (Such as multiple death fake outs that become deus ex machinas). I am really not a fan of the proposed "Hasbro Cinematic Universe" teased during this final act and overall, it felt like it was losing steam as the film went along, throwing many ideas at the board and seeing what stuck. At 2 hours, it really started to drag towards the end. Overall, Transformers: Rise of the Beasts is a disappointment and I can only hope that the next entry is better.

Grew up on Transformers (#80sBaby) but completely gave up on the franchise after the first installment. Michael Bay has a place film, but his interpretation of the TF IP was wildly over the top with storylines that focused on the wrong thing - the humans. TF I knew and loved wasn't about an unnecessary love story/interest/drama/triangle or father/daughter rescue storyline...it was about, erhm, the friggin TRANSFORMERS!! I stayed away from any/all installments from then on (including Bumblebee, which I've since rectified). Once I heard they were releasing a new TF movie in 2023 I groaned, but then I heard the name...could it be they finally introducing the Maximals!? I'd loved the show Beasts Wars when it was on, at the point of even being ridiculed by friends, so this was big. But also potentially yet another disaster. My disappointment from the Bay-era kept me from seeing Beasts while in theaters, but a fateful visit to my mom's house, courisority and a lazy afternoon led to a digital rental viewing experience. My expectations? Beyond low. My skepticism? Major. My momma? Ecstatic (shes loved every TF movie since 2007). Within the OPENING SCENE, I was already hopeful. It was them. The Maximals. Optiumus Primal. Wow. The special effects, voices. Everything, it was there (welp, except Rattrap) It only got better from the title screen - being set in the 90s allowed for a great prequel storyline (+epic music choices) and the ability to try and mend the pain of the overly-everything Bay-era. Probably would've made a few minor tweaks, but I legit laughed out loud mutilple times, arms-in-air cheered more than once and even teared up a few times. This movie gave me everything I didn't know I wanted or needed, and than gave me more with not 1 but 2 end credit scenes! To say I enjoyed it would be an understatement and ended up purchasing it once the rental expired. This movie was so good, I ended up watching the entire franchise (all for the first time except the 2007 OG) which 1000% confirmed my belief the Bay-era was horrendous and franchise deserve better. Bumblebee started it, Beasts continued it and I am now excited and hopefully to see where it goes from here. Side note - This whole review might sound dramatic, but please believe I'm very serious, lol. If you've made it to the end, thanks for reading

There is no way possible this movie got a 91% audience score. This movie is beyond terrible. Why does it seem that whomever is making these films are purposely going out of their way to ignore all the source material? Go out of their way to change the design, and personalities of every Transformer? In some cases completely change the alt mode from one character to another. Why did Mirage have Jazz's alt mode? What they did to Wheeljack in this film, was inexcusable. I cannot think of any valid reason for them to do what they did to him. Especially after seeing how he could have looked from the Cybertron scene in Bumblebee. They have to know that everyone wants a movie, like what we saw in the first 10 minutes of Bumblebee. Why do they just refuse to do this? We want a G1 inspired franchise. They could create a whole universe from this source material. 1st movie, work on the origins of Prime and Megatron. Tell the story of why Megatron became the way he did. Then move on to the war of cybertron and then end that movie with them crashing on Earth a million year ago. 2nd movie. Start where the last ended, but in current times. They have been in stasis this whole time, but are awaken and repaired with alt modes from their surroundings (also don't allow them to just change their alt mode whenever it's convenient, what they have is what they get.) 3rd movie. This is where we could maybe introduce Unicron, basically this could be a modern retelling of the 84 movie. But don't introduce all the G2ish characters, don't need to see Blur. But Optimus really does die in this one, doesn't come back. Megatron is reformatted into Galvatron. Everyone they introduce needs character development or don't have them in the film. This could even be a 2 part film, to allow them time to develop and tell the story. 4th movie. A true Beast wars movie, starts off in the way distant future. They can explain how the Autobots and Decepticons are extinct and the maximals and predicons are the decendants. BW Megatron has always had greater ambitions and then learns about the golden disk with the message from Megatron. Basically now, a movie similar to the original BW show. This can all be done, and would at the same time build a universe of connected movies. But instead, we get the exact same film over and over and over (with apparently no connection to the movies that came out before it). New unneeded human characters find artifact. Meet random transformer, hunt for other artifacts. Human saves day. We are so tired of this garbage. Why they refuse to give us the movies we want is baffling.

Pretty much everything about this is fundamentally ok. This is basically a retelling of the first with some elements of the sequels mixed in for good measure. The rap soundtrack mixed in with cinematic is kind of a strange choice and is very hit or miss. Especially during the action scenes the rap numbers seem out of place. The CGI is shotty with the Bird looking not tha good, oversaturation at the end fight, solid work on Prime, its a bit all over the place. Also the action scenes are very simliar to what weve seen before in all the other ones. It is jumpy a bit in the start, but settles down in the second half. The new autobots aren't used for much besides plot expose dumps every 20 minutes or so and lack much character. That also goes for the human characters who are just ok as well and follow the same beats Shia & Mark followed. It's nothing we haven't seen before in this franchise and done better. The digital scenes look out of place as well and feel like there from a entirely different movie. The end fight does drag a bit as well keeping up with tradition of the other sequels. This is better than those mainly because the excess and Bay tropes aren't present in this and this feels like a basic stripped down Transformers sequel but thats the main problem. It is predictable the entire way for the most part but is competant. If you wanna see giant robots fight again than you'll get your money. If your most and wanna see something different and not just a retelling of the first or previous ones again than skip this and stick with the first & Bumblebee.

Transformers: Rise of the Beasts is a really great new addition to the franchise as the film follows Noah who is played by the amazing Anthony Ramos who I know as Usnavi from In the Heights, as he falls into the lap of an Autobot named Mirage and is sucked into having to save the world. This movie I believe is much more entertaining and action packed as Bumblebee was and has a much more complex story as it dives more into the lore of Transformers with the arc known as Beast Wars. This movie feels really similar to Revenge of the Fallen as it dives into that National Treasure or Indiana Jones feel of things. I also really enjoyed the dynamic between not only Mirage and Noah within the movie but more so Noah and Optimus as they do butt heads a little, realizing they have more in common than they think which I enjoy their dynamic better than Sam and Optimus, but Sam's dynamic with Bumblebee can't be beaten in my opinion. I found a lot of Mirage's jokes within the movie to be funny, mostly due to the fact I get a kick out of Pete Davidson as it is. I also really enjoyed how more accurate the transformers' designs were to the cartoons even though the Bay designs will always have a special place in my heart. I'm just so glad that Transformers is still showing that they have gas in the tank when it comes to the intense action that will give you suspense, make you engaged, and still deliver a great story. Overall, Rise of the Beasts is a great movie with a charming cast and has some great character development and chemistry while also keeping the action-packing and bringing back that adventure aspect to these movies. Rise of the Beasts is a B+.

While the original 2007 Transformers film wasn't perfect, it was a movie for fans of the cartoon. I can still go back and watch that one with the joy I felt the first time I saw it. The graphics look more like a cartoon and the Autobots dialogue was straight out of the campy TV show sans the respect for Prime. None of the sequels seemed to ackowledge much about the mythology from the previous movie - but this one tries to tie to the original show's plot while creating a completely ridiculous new mythology. The fact the Michael Bay even has his name on this one shocks me. Complete garbage.

I went into this movie having high hopes based on reviews from audiences. However I was let down. I think the main problem is that it feels rushed. I felt like I wasn't given enough backstory for the human characters and therefore didn't really care about them. I also felt like we werent given enough explanation to the plot and therefore it was hard to care about what the transformers were trying to do. We also have a whole new cast of transformers that we also aren't introduced to very well. I also feel like optimus prime has changed character completely. In the bay movies he is a very strong and confident leader. However in this film it feels like he has lost his leadership and is quite boring. Another problem is that the cgi is different to the bay movies. While it is mostly still good. The transformers look a lot more cartoony. Overall I would say that if you are a fan of the original cartoon from the 80s you will probably enjoy this film. However If you are a big fan of the bay movies you probably won't enjoy this one as much.

The movie doesn't make any sense for the timeline it's supposed to fit into, the movie forces humor instead of the seriousness of the plot, prime has no sense of respectful leadership, they bid the life of every galaxy in existence on not wanting to be seen by humans, there is no significant loss because of the timeliness we know that the one character that dies is going to be resurrected, the cgi seems different in a bad way, not as much detail as the movies before it, there's nearly no backstory to the main character, character reactions are not all there in certain scenes, feels like a rip off of king Kong and Ironman as they perform the same moves at times, if it was the first movie of a new series spin off made for kids (because there's no gore or death) then I would rate it 5/5, but for the series it's supposed to be a part of, I would say save your money and watch the next fast and furious 29 or whatever number there on, it feels like a wasted hour of my life to watch this series die, very sad and disappointing to have watched these movies growing up from a kid being super excited to watch this new one just for it to tank the series for anyone who has watched the previous movies The movie doesn't pull the viewers in and get them attached to anything or anyone, they could have made the movie better by having the main character choose between saving his brother or the world, at least then people would be emotionally invested in something

Just terrible. Spoiler alert in this review. Unless this was supposed to be a full restart of the movie franchise it made no sense. It is a prequel set in the 90s but makes no attempt to fit in with the other movies. We start with the Maximals on another planet, why are they animals? The auto bots chose cars to hide on earth, did that planet have the same animals as earth? Although they are giant versions of animals so they still don't fit in. The villain comes to destroy their home planet and their leader dies trying to stall. He fights the villain as a gorilla, so you assume that they don't have the ability to transform because otherwise why would you do that? Later we learn they can transform into robots with weapons, maybe their leader was just an idiot. We then are introduced to the humans with minimal background of both other than the fact that they are street smart and face racism. The male is supposed to be good with electronics - this never becomes a valuable skill. The female is an intern at a museum whose director uses her as an expert who gets no credit. We never get any background as to how she has so much knowledge of antiquities other than the fact that her dad was smart from looking things up on his own despite no college education. The male encounters the auto bots and is used to help them retrieve a newly discovered inter dimensional key at the museum. However they are intercepted by the villain who proceeds to beat up all the auto bots and steals the key (turns out to only be half). Optimus, generally the most experienced, wisest, and level headed transformer immediately blames the humans even though they had no knowledge of the villains and the villains managed to defeat every autobot. They then need to find the second half of the key which the female found through similar symbols in Peru. The only explanation as to why the humans are coming is the male doesn't want to trust the planets safety in their hands, as if he provides any help in a fight against giant advanced robots, and the female must come to help them find the location in Peru? They don't have gps or ability to access the internet as a technically advanced race of robots??

By far the worst Transformers movie. The worst part is it totally destroyed any time line of the movies. 1994,,, really. Then when did the Shai LaBeouf, Mark Walberg, and Bumblebee movies take place. The 70's and 80's??? Or are they all fighting different parts of the war at the same time. Stupid mess up of the time line. No character build up. Who are these people. 20 minutes into the movie and these 2 humans are faced with giant robot aliens. They have no fear or suspicion. Learn their technology. Then go and fight with Unicron with no problems. Oh wait,,, one guy needed money so... No thank you. Waited, and watched good movies for years waiting for this crappie 2 hour cut grab at money for the franchise. I been a fan of Transformers since the 80's cartoon, the Beast Wars, no w the live action movies. You boys at the Transformers movie franchise camp failed your viewers on this one. This would have been a great 2 part series. Please dont ruin it by trying again.

Wow. This dreadful movie makes the previous Bay movies seem like award winning masterpieces. The casting is dreadful, and the writing was like that of a 6 year old. The movie goes nowhere and there's zero investment in any of the characters. This reboot needs a whole new reboot or let's go back to the Bayverse with a new cast.
